Literature Review: Mimas, the smallest and innermost of Saturn's mid-sized moons, has long been a subject of interest in the field of planetary science. The moon's heavily cratered surface and lack of intricate fracture systems have led to debates about its geological history and orbital evolution. Recent Cassini measurements have provided evidence of an ocean beneath Mimas' ice shell, sparking renewed interest in the moon's potential as an ocean world. This literature review aims to summarize the current understanding of Mimas' geologic history, orbital evolution, and the implications of its ocean-bearing status for the habitability of other moons in the Saturn system and beyond.

References.title: The Geology of Mimas
References.authors: L. A. Young, J. M. Head, and J. M. Kargel

References.title: Mimas: A Moon with a Hidden Ocean
The Formation of Gaps in Saturn's Rings
Tidal Heating and the Habitability of Enceladus
The Ocean-Bearing Mimas: A New Perspective
Mimas: A New Frontier for Ocean Worlds Research
